subject: Re: [junit] Re: Eclipse + Ant + JUnit
msgSnippet: THanks for all the help!  I think that is working now.  I had multiple versions of the commons-configuration in my path. Angela Igor A. Deruga
messageBody:
THanks for all the help! I think that is working now. I had multiple versions of the commons-configuration in my path.

Angela

"Igor A. Deruga" <ingvarrr@...> wrote:

Hi, Ladies! Good daytime, Alistair!

I think that the easiest solution to this problem is defining individual
classpaths that include every directory you want to include. I made it like
this (though this may be an ugly way of using filesets... It's up to you to
improve it):
//----------------------build.xml part------------------
<path id="build.class.path">
<fileset dir="${lib.dir}">
<include name="*.jar" />
</fileset>
</path>

<path id="test.class.path">
<path refid="build.class.path" />
</path>
.................
<target name="test" .....
<junit printsummary="on" fork="true">
<classpath refid="test.class.path"/>
..............
//----------------------End of build.xml part------------------

Now you don't depend on the settings in Eclipse or CLASSPATH variable in your
environment.

The only thing you should remember is that you have to add "junit.jar" to
Window->Preferences...->classpath (as Pam told you).

Also I usually add all that stuff to Eclipse too for composing purposes (to
enable Content Assist, etc.).

Hope this helps. If you find any mistakes, please, do me a favor and inform
me.

Cheers
Igor

On Monday 15 November 2004 01:35, pam withnall wrote:
> One thing I found with running ants build.xml within Eclipse, is that it
> doesn't use the library/classpath settings for the java project, you
> need to set all those again in Window->
> Preferences->ant->runtime->classpath to run ant.
> Pam.
